questions.question:
Question 2: A physician prescribes clonazepam to a patient with generalized anxiety disorder. Choose the 
false statement regarding its mechanism of action.

options.a: Bind at the  / interface of GABA-A receptor
options.b: Increase the affinity of the GABA-A receptor for GABA
options.c: Activate GABA-A receptors directly opening the Cl channel
options.d: Increase the frequency of opening of GABA receptor Cl channel

questions.explanation:
Clonazepam is a benzodiazepine. These are allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor. They do 
not directly activate GABAA receptors to open the Cl- channel. GABAA receptor is a transmembrane inhibitory receptor in the CNS that functions as a chloride 
ion channel and has 5 subunits. Benzodiazepines are allosteric modulators of the GABAA receptor that bind at the  / interface of 
the receptor. This increases the affinity of the GABAA receptor for GABA thus increasing the 263 
Sold by @itachibot frequency of the opening of the channel. Barbiturates, on the other hand, have a different binding site to the receptor and they increase the 
duration of the GABA gated chloride channel opening.

questions.question: Question 3: Which is the shortest acting benzodiazepine?
questions.explanation: Remimazolam is the shortest-acting benzodiazepine. Its half-life is just around 37-53 mins. Classification of benzodiazepines: • Long-acting: • Flurazepam • Diazepam • Quazepam • Chlordiazepoxide • Intermediate-acting: • Alprazolam • Temazepam • Lorazepam • Short-acting: • Triazolam • Midazolam • Ultra-short acting • Remimazolam Note: Remimazolam was approved by FDA in 2020.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following does not act via GABA potentiation?
questions.explanation: Promethazine does not act via GABA potentiation. It is a first-generation H1 receptor antagonist. Zopiclone, midazolam, and thiopentone act via GABA potentiation.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient diagnosed with insomnia is taking a drug belonging to the Z-compounds family. 
Which of the following does not belong to this family?
questions.explanation:
Zonisamide is a sulfonamide anticonvulsant drug, that has no activity on GABA receptors. It does 
not belong to the Z-compound drugs. It is an adjunct drug for Parkinson's disease, partial-onset 
seizures, infantile spasm, mixed seizure types of Lennox–Gastaut syndrome, myoclonic and 
generalized tonic-clonic seizure. 264 
Sold by @itachibot Z compounds are benzodiazepine receptor agonists. They have less anticonvulsant and muscle 
relaxant properties when compared to benzodiazepines. They are used for the treatment of insomnia. They include: • Zolpidem • Zaleplon • Zopiclone • Eszopiclone

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following agents does not bind to GABA receptor chloride channel complex?
questions.explanation:
Buspirone does not bind to the GABA receptor chloride channel complex. It is a partial 
agonist at 5-HT1A receptor used in the treatment of anxiety. Option A: Ethanol releases GABA and also has a binding site on the GABA receptor chloride 
channel complex. Option B: Alphaxolone is a neurosteroid and it acts through activation of GABAA receptors. These 
receptors are BZD insensitive. Option C: Zolpidem belongs to novel benzodiazepine receptor agonists called Z compounds. It 
binds to the BZD receptor present on the GABA receptor chloride channel complex.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is an inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine receptor?
questions.explanation:
The inverse agonist at the benzodiazepine receptor is beta-carboline. It impedes the action of GABA and can cause anxiogenic, convulsive, and memory-enhancing 
effects. Option A: Barbiturates (phenobarbitone) are agonists at an allosteric site on the GABAA receptor 
that facilitate the action of GABA. Option C: Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor. Option D: Picrotoxin blocks Cl- channel non-competitively.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 33-year-old woman with suspected diazepam overdose was administered the antidote for 
benzodiazepine poisoning. Which of the following statements is false about this antidote?

options.a: It is a specific antagonist of benzodiazepines
options.b: It may be used to treat barbiturate poisoning
options.d: It acts at the same site on GABA channel where benzodiazepines bind

questions.explanation:
Flumazenil is the antidote used in benzodiazepine poisoning. It is not used to treat barbiturate 
poisoning. Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine (BZD) receptor-specific antagonist. It has no affinity for 
barbiturate binding sites on the GABA receptor Cl- channel complex. Flumazenil competes with 
BZD agonists and inverse agonists for the BZD receptors. 265 
Sold by @itachibot Flumazenil is available only for intravenous use. It is used to treat benzodiazepine overdose and 
for the reversal of sedative effects produced by benzodiazepines administered during general 
anesthesia.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is a competitive antagonist of GABA at the GABA-A receptor?
questions.explanation:
Bicuculline is a competitive antagonist of GABA at the GABA-A receptor. Option A: Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the alpha/gamma interface of the 
benzodiazepine site. This is different from the binding site of GABA which is the alpha/beta 
interface. Option B: Picrotoxin blocks Cl- channel non-competitively. Option D: Propofol is an agonist at the GABA-A receptor. Note: Muscimol is an agonist at the GABA-A receptor.

questions.question: Question 10: In which of the following patients is the administration of barbiturates contraindicated?

options.a: 29-year-old lady with history of anxiety disorder
options.b: 33-year-old man with history of acute intermittent porphyria

questions.explanation:
The administration of barbiturates is contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria. The rate-limiting enzyme in porphyria synthesis is -aminolaevulinic acid (ALA)-synthetase. 
Barbiturates are enzyme inducers and they result in the increased synthesis of porphyrins and 
subsequent precipitation of acute intermittent porphyria. Options A and C: Barbiturates are used to treat anxiety and refractory status epilepticus. Option D: Phenobarbitone can be used to treat kernicterus in newborns as it increases hepatic 
glucuronosyltransferase (UGT) enzyme activity and the conjugation of bilirubin. 266 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 28-year-old man with insomnia is prescribed a melatonin analog by his physician. Which of 
the following drugs would have been prescribed?
questions.explanation:
Ramelteon is a melatonin analog approved for the treatment of insomnia, particularly with 
difficulties of sleep onset. It acts on both MT1 and MT2 receptors. • MT1 receptor - promotes the onset of sleep (hence used for induction of sleep) • MT2 receptor - shifts the timing of the circadian system. The other melatonin agonists are: • Tasimelteon - used in insomnia in blind people • Agomelatine - used in major depressive disorder Option A: Doxepin is a tricyclic antidepressant and functions as a serotonin-norepinephrine 
reuptake inhibitor. It is used in depression, anxiety, and some forms of insomnia. Option B: Suvorexant is a dual orexin receptor antagonist used in the treatment of insomnia. Option D: Trazodone is a mixed agonist and antagonist at various serotonin receptors used as an 
antidepressant and in alcohol dependence.

questions.question:
Question 12: A young woman, who is blind, presented with complaints of night-time insomnia. What is the 
drug of choice for her condition? 261 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is tasimelteon. It is a selective agonist of the 
melatonin (MT1, MT2) receptors. Tasimelteon is approved for the treatment of non–24-h sleep-wake syndrome (nighttime insomnia 
and daytime sleepiness, alternating with asymptomatic periods) in totally blind patients 
experiencing circadian rhythm disorder.

questions.question:
Question 13: Your senior resident asks you to prescribe an orexin receptor inhibitor to a patient with 
insomnia. Which of the following drugs would you prescribe?
questions.explanation:
Suvorexant is an inhibitor of both orexin1 and orexin2 receptors. It is approved for the treatment 
of insomnia. Orexins are produced in the lateral hypothalamus neurons and play a major role in maintaining 
the sleep cycle. Orexins promote wakefulness, while antagonists at orexin receptors enhance REM 
and non-REM sleep. Option B: Doxepin is a tricyclic antidepressant and has H1 receptor antagonism effect. It is used 
for insomnia at lower doses. Option C: Ritanserin is a 5HT2A/2C receptor antagonist indicated in insomnia. Option D: Agomelatine is a melatonin receptor agonist and a 5HT2C receptor antagonist indicated 
in insomnia. 267 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 68-year-old man with alcoholic liver disease is scheduled to undergo surgery. Which of the 
following benzodiazepines should be avoided in him?

options.c: Causes hyperphosphatemia in renal failure patients
options.d: ECG monitoring is not required when administering IV

questions.explanation:
Diazepam and its long-acting metabolites can accumulate significantly in elderly patients with 
liver disease and therefore should not be used in such cases. Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine. It is metabolized in the liver to active metabolites like 
nordazepam which are long-acting. Nordazepam is further converted to oxazepam which is 
conjugated with glucuronic acid to form inactive metabolites. Lorazepam, oxazepam, and triazolam are also metabolized in the liver but do not form long-acting 
active metabolites. As such, they can be used in elderly patients with liver disease but with 
caution. Oxazepam and lorazepam are intermediate-acting and undergo glucuronide conjugation directly 
to form inactive metabolites. Triazolam is a short acting benzodiazepine. It forms alpha-hydroxy active metabolites but they are 
short-acting and undergo glucuronide conjugation to form inactive metabolites. 268 
Sold by @itachibot Anti-epileptics I
